<nowiki>[[http://connman.net/|Connection Manager]]</nowiki> (ConnMan) is a daemon for managing internet connections in Linux. The Connection Manager is designed to be slim and to use as few resources as possible, so it can be easily integrated. The primary use case is embedded systems, but it can be also used in desktop environments.

<nowiki>[[http://ofono.org/|oFono]]</nowiki> is a mobile telephony stack for Linux. For Connman it provides access to data modems so that a connection to Internet can be created.

Ubuntu has <nowiki>[[https://launchpad.net/indicator-network|Network Menu]]</nowiki> as the frontend for ConnMan. It uses <nowiki>[[DesktopExperienceTeam-ApplicationIndicators|Application Indicator framework]]</nowiki> to show the menu to the user and provides various dialogs needed for managing Internet connections.

The goal is to have all this working in Ubuntu Netbook Edition (UNE), but all the components work also with the Desktop edition.

=== Status ===

The packages are now included in Ubuntu 10.10, but are not installed by default and needs to be manually installed. UI components are still under state of flux, but most of the features should work now.

Supported features:

* Ethernet
* Wi-Fi Open, WEP, WPA and WPA2
* 3G on GSM networks
* BT PAN
* IPv6

Notable missing features:

* VPN (<nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/connman/+bug/586893|bug #586893]]</nowiki>)
* Wi-Fi Ad-Hoc (<nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/connman/+bug/703889|bug #703889]]</nowiki>)
* WPA Enterprise (<nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/indicator-network/+bug/730158|bug #730158]]</nowiki>)
* CDMA/EVDO modem support
* BT DUN
* PPPoE (<nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/connman/+bug/735457|bug #735457]]</nowiki>)
